Representing a round settlement, walled and divided by crossroads. Similar settlements are archaeologically attested in Upper Egypt since the earliest periods of urbanization.  

![](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c0/Abydos-Bold-hieroglyph-O49B.png/39px-Abydos-Bold-hieroglyph-O49B.png)

Wheel is [PIE](PIE) technology:  
[why.they.lost.the.wheel](http://archive.aramcoworld.com/issue/197303/why.they.lost.the.wheel.htm)  
Furthermore, the Turks in early times used carts without roads on the Central Asian steppe, as did the unknown ancient inhabitants of the Sahara Desert.  
The word "araba" or arabiya, which is so commonly used today in both Turkish and Arabic denotes a wheeled vehicle ğ“Š–ğ“Š–ğ“Š–ğ“Š– Arba = 4 â‡” Orbit ğ“Š–  

Samarra Bowl (ca. 4000 BC)  
![samarra_bowl.png](samarra_bowl.png)  
The ğ“Š– sign is a slightly more neutral symbol than the [swastika](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swastika), though it's history is not very peaceful either. ğ“Š– Warkar was related to War and hard work. ğ“Š– Kur is related to Kerker (gaol). Things have improved significantly since the formation period, with the exception of an overly zealous destruction of [nature](ğ“…).

Careful: The Arkaim (ArchaeHeim ğŸ—¿) structure consists of three concentric rings of walls and three (Æ’!?) radial streets , reflecting the city of King Yima described in the Rigveda. The foundation walls and the dwellings of the second ring are built according to what some researchers have described as [[swastika]]-like patterns; the same symbol is found on various artifacts.
